content: The Act titled "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2003" excludes space-related income from gross income according to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2003" excludes space-related income from gross income as defined in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Space-related income includes income from products or services produced or provided in outer space. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2003" excludes income from products or services produced or provided in outer space from gross income as defined in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This includes income from services performed in outer space, as well as interest, rent, royalty, or similar amounts related to space production or services. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2003" excludes income from services performed in outer space, interest, rent, royalty, or similar amounts related to space production or services. Telecommunications services from earth orbit and services from weather or earth observation satellites are exceptions. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2003" excludes certain services provided in outer space from income taxation, including telecommunications services from earth orbit, services from weather or earth observation satellites, and property transportation services to or from outer space. Additionally, wages received by employees are exempt from this provision. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2003" exempts property transportation services to or from outer space from income taxation. Wages received by employees are not covered by this exemption. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2003" exempts space-related income from taxation for products produced partly in space. The term "produced" includes various methods like created, fabricated, developed, grown, manufactured, extracted, processed, cured, and aged. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2003" excludes expenses for products manufactured in outer space from tariffs. The term "produced" encompasses various methods like created, fabricated, developed, grown, manufactured, extracted, processed, cured, and aged. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2003" exempts products manufactured in outer space from federal tariffs, excises, imposts, and duties. This exemption applies to products launched from and returned to Earth within the United States or manufactured at a facility in outer space owned by U.S. persons. The benefits of this exemption will phase out for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2012. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2003" exempts products manufactured in outer space owned by U.S. persons from federal tariffs, excises, imposts, and duties. The benefits of this exemption will phase out for taxable years starting after December 31, 2012. Beginning after December 31, 2012, the excluded amount under subsection (a) will be reduced by x/10th's of the amount excludable without regard to this subsection, where 'x' is the number of years after the last taxable year before January 1, 2013. A similar rule applies to benefits under subsection (c). Additionally, a clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for part III of subchapter B of chapter 1 of the Code. SEC. 140 and 140A relate to space-related income and cross-references to other Acts. The effective date for these amendments is for taxable years starting after December 31, 2003. SEC. 3 introduces a credit for the purchase of qualified space company stock under SEC. 45G. The space company investment credit is determined by the amount paid for qualified stock in a qualified space company. A qualified space company is a domestic C corporation with average annual gross receipts not exceeding $100,000,000 for the 3-taxable-year period before the purchase of qualified stock. A qualified space company, defined as a domestic C corporation, must meet specific criteria to be eligible for the space company investment credit. This includes having average annual gross receipts not exceeding $100,000,000, with more than 70 percent of gross receipts derived from space-based business activities. Space-based business is defined as a business with substantially space-related income. The term 'qualified stock' in a domestic C corporation for the space company investment credit is defined as any stock meeting specific criteria, with average annual gross receipts not exceeding $100,000,000 and more than 70 percent derived from space-based business activities. Space-based business refers to a business with substantially space-related income. Rules similar to section 1202(d)(3) apply for aggregation in section 140(b). Qualified stock in a domestic C corporation for the space company investment credit must meet specific criteria and be acquired at its original issue by the taxpayer. Qualified stock in a domestic C corporation for the space company investment credit must be acquired at its original issue by the taxpayer, in exchange for money, property, or as compensation for services provided to the corporation. Qualified stock in a domestic C corporation for the space company investment credit must be acquired at its original issue by the taxpayer in exchange for money, property, or as compensation for services provided to the corporation. The stock must meet active business requirements during the taxpayer's holding period. During the taxpayer's holding period, qualified stock in a C corporation for the space company investment credit must meet active business requirements similar to section 1202(e) for a space-based business and be a C corporation. During the taxpayer's holding period, qualified stock in a C corporation for the space company investment credit must meet requirements similar to section 1202(e) for a space-based business and be a C corporation. Rules similar to section 1202(c)(3) apply for the purchase of its own stock. If the issuer of the stock ceases to be a qualified space company within 10 years, recapture rules apply. Rules similar to section 1202(c)(3) apply for the purchase of qualified stock in a C corporation for the space company investment credit. If the issuer of the stock ceases to be a qualified space company within 10 years, recapture rules apply. This section does not apply to stock acquired after December 31, 2011. The section allows for a credit related to space company investments, with rules for recapture if the company ceases to qualify. The provision does not apply to stock acquired after December 31, 2011. The amendment allows for a space company investment credit under section 45G(a) of the Code, with no carryback before January 1, 2004. The amendment introduces a space company investment credit under section 45G(a) of the Code, with no carryback allowed before January 1, 2004. The amendment allows for the space company investment credit under section 45G(a) to be carried back to a taxable year before January 1, 2004. The amendment allows for the space company investment credit under section 45G(a) to be carried back to a taxable year before January 1, 2004. The table of sections for subpart D of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Code is amended to include a new item for the space company investment credit. The amendment allows for the space company investment credit under section 45G to be applied to costs incurred after December 31, 2003. Additionally, a new section 1203 is added to provide an exclusion for gains from the sale or exchange of stock of qualified space corporations. The exclusion of gain on the sale or exchange of stock of a qualified space corporation is defined as a domestic C corporation organized for providing products or services in outer space. A qualified space corporation must be organized exclusively for providing products or services in outer space, with at least 90 percent of expenses related to this activity. A qualified space corporation must be organized exclusively for providing products or services in outer space, with at least 90 percent of expenses related to this activity. The corporation should not provide services, products, or articles described in section 140(b)(2). The amendments made by this section exclude gains from the sale or exchange of stock of qualified space corporations. Effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2003.
